Configuration.StudyNameEntrez: Whole Exome Sequencing in Familial Parkinson Disease
Configuration.StudyNameReportPage: Whole Exome Sequencing in Familial Parkinson Disease
Configuration.Description: We have an ongoing study that has recruited families having at least a sibling pair with Parkinson disease (PD). Families have been screened for mutations in known PD causative genes (LRRK2, parkin, etc). Following review of families without a causative mutation, we selected families for whole exome sequencing that had the strongest history of PD and with the most definitive diagnosis. All families have at least 3 affected family members who were evaluated as part of this study. Only affected family members were included for whole exome sequencing.
Configuration.StudyInEx: Family members were evaluated, whenever possible, in person using a series of standard case report forms. The UK Brain Bank criteria were implemented as a Diagnostic Checklist (Pankratz et al., 2002) and all individuals included for sequencing met the modified UK Brain Bank criteria. The modified criteria allows for a family history of PD.

Header.title: Principal Investigator
Header.Institution: Indiana University School of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA

Header.title: Funding Source
Header.AttName: Parkinson Disease Collaborative Study of Genetic Linkage
Header.Institution: National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA

Configuration.StudyHistory: This study ascertained families having 2 living siblings diagnosed with Parkinson disease (PD). The families were screened for mutations in known genes (Nichols et al., Lancet, 2005; Pankratz et al., Neurology, 2009). Linkage analysis (Pankratz et al., HMG, 2003) was performed as well as a genomewide association study (Pankratz et al., Human Genetics, 2009).

ConsentGroup.longName: Subjects did not participate in the study, did not complete a consent document and are included only for the pedigree structure and/or genotype controls, such as HapMap subjects
Disease-Specific (Parkinson's disease or other neurodegenerative disorders)
